document_data.caption: An arm, leg, and eye replacement.
document_data.name: Prosthetic
document_data.value2e:
{{Split table|rca=center|caption=Clockwork limbs| captionstyle=font-family:serif;font-style:italic; | leftheader=Limb Type|rightheader=Price | rhstyle = color:black;text-align:center;|Arm|20,000 [[gp]]|Leg|10,000 gp|Hand|7,500 gp}}
{{Split table|rca=center|caption=Hooks| captionstyle=font-family:serif;font-style:italic; | leftheader=Material|rightheader=Price | rhstyle = color:black;text-align:center;|[[Gold]]|95 gp|[[Silver]]|9 gp|[[Brass]]|9 gp|[[Steel]]|3 [[sp]]}}
{{Split table|rca=center|caption=Pegs| captionstyle=font-family:serif;font-style:italic; | leftheader=Material|rightheader=Price | rhstyle = color:black;text-align:center;|Gold|170 gp|Silver|18 gp|Brass|18 gp|[[Ivory]]|2 gp|Steel|7 sp|Wood|7 [[cp]]}}
document_data.text: ...werk compensatorily by grantin' in flair what they takes in facil'ty.
document_data.source: One pirate describing their hook or peg leg.
document_data.mainbody:
* [[Angar Axeson]], a [[dwarf]] warrior and blacksmith, had a steel prosthetic orb in place of his right eye after having lost the real one during the [[Reclamation Wars|Tethyrian Civil War]].
* Arla Razortongue.
* [[Baelam]], a wizard who had his left hand replaced with the hand of a strange [[iron golem]].
* [[Belwar Dissengulp]], one of the [[svirfneblin]] of [[Blingdenstone]], had two prosthetic hands. Much like a hook-hand these consisted of a metal cup, but in place of a hook one was tipped with a [[hammer]] and the other a [[pick]].<ref>{{Cite comic/The Legend of Drizzt: Exile 1}}
* Cilaen Irontoes, an inhabitant of the [[Sigil/The Lady's Ward|Lady's Ward]] of [[Sigil]] who had iron prosthetic toes after his brother dropped a {{SI|50|lbs.|k}} stone on his feet.<ref>
* [[Colis Goldsfall]], a tavern owner in [[Trailstone]], had a peg leg.<ref>
* [[Crannak Smoulderburn]] had an iron prosthetic of a clenched fist.
* [[Essimuth Lanys]], a merchant and retired adventurer who owned three elaborately carved peg legs. The one he typically wore was carved to resemble an [[owlbear]] holding up his leg. For formal occasions, he wore a [[duskwood]] peg leg carved with the shield and coat of arms of [[Waterdeep]]. Finally, during the winter season he wore an ivory peg leg carved like a rearing [[white dragon]], which had grooves to give him better traction on ice and snow.<ref>
* [[Ezmerelda d'Avenir]], a monster hunter in the [[Domains of Dread]], had a prosthetic made for her lower right leg after it was bitten off by a [[werewolf]].
* [[Findlewulf]], a tavern owner in [[Skullport]], had a wooden peg leg after suffering a [[shark]] attack.
* [[Granz Stronghand]], a [[Ravens Bluff|Ravenian]] sailor, had a [[walnut]] peg leg that had carvings of [[seaweed]] fronds.
* [[Hethyl Arkorran]], a dwarven member of the [[Knights of the Black Sword]], had a right peg-leg after having lost her foot to [[frostbite (condition)|frostbite]].<ref>
* [[Hlondaglus Shrim]] had a wooden leg.
* [[Immurk|Immurk the Invincible]], the first great pirate of the Pirate Isles.
* [[Kaverin Ebonhand]] had both of his hands cut off as a punishment for murder. His [[wizard]] lawyer created two hands of animated black stone for Kaverin.
* [[Maliceprow]] had a hook hand made of [[mithral]].<ref>{{Cite digital book/Rising Tide|?|30}}
* [[Ott Steeltoes]]
* [[Rufus Railsplitter]], a Ravenian bar owner skilled in bargaining, once lost his left hand to a "creditor" due to a gambling debt. In its place, Rufus wore a leather armguard that terminated in a broad, flat metal blade.<ref>{{Cite polyhedron/60/The Living City: The Dancing Bear Inn|24}}
* [[Rusty Al]], a merchant and [[tattoo]]ist in [[Neverwinter]] that had a hook hand.
* [[Talton]], a Ravenian [[thief]], had a wooden leg.
* [[Vangol Kuskolt]], a dwarven [[priest]] of [[Tyr]] with an iron peg leg. In his duties as a judge in the town of [[Leilon]], he would brand criminals using his iron leg, which he would first super-heat in a fire.
* [[Voron Orama]], a Ravenian [[moon elf]] tavern keeper, had a gleaming metal arm.
* [[Welverin Freth]] had a prosthetic silver leg.
* [[Wyll Ravengard]] had a prosthetic ''[[sending stone]]'' right eye.<ref>
* [[Zariel]], Archduke of [[Avernus]], had her left hand replaced with a powerful [[flail]] after losing it in [[Hell]].{{Cite MTG|AFR|285}}

Varieties.Gondar prosthetics: The [[Church of Gond]]'s members had their own distinct variety of prosthetic limbs that had a great "yoke" that would attach to their wearer. They were known for their proficiently articulated joints, with feet flexing at the ankle, hands having gripping power, and fingers able to be pointed. The most expensive of these prosthetics were laced with [[spell]]s that kept them bonded to a user and allowed for good motor control, though Gondar clerics had to be paid to renew this magic.<ref>{{Cite web/theedverse/2021-10-11 - Gondar Prosthetics}}
Varieties.Kalgalast prosthetics: A variety of highly realistic limbs that were sold in the late 14{{th}} century DR by the traveling craftsmen [[Orviir Kalgalast]]. These multi-jointed limbs were made of a combination of wood and metal, covered in a [[rubber]] sleeve, and enchanted to protect against wear-and-tear (including cracking, melting, or weathering from sunlight or frigid temperatures). They were designed for humans, [[elves]], [[half-elves]], and [[halfling]]s. They could also be ordered to have certain skin hues or fingernail styles. These limbs could be quite expensive, with jointed limbs with full strappings but no rubber sleeve, costing around 2,200 gp, whilst merely a replacement "under-piece" (such as part of a joint, or a forearm) would fetch 600 gp. And for larger than average individuals, a limb could cost as much as 4,000 gp. Additionally, at triple the base price, Kalgalast could incorporate retractable weapons or hiding-cavities. Rumors, attested to by [[Elminster]], spoke of these prosthethics exploding on those who didn't pay fully for them, sometimes resulting in the wearer's death.<ref>{{Cite web/Forging the Realms/So What Do Ye Do for a Living?}}

document_data.Notable Prosthetics:
;Ebony hands
:One knowledgeable [[wizard]] was able to create for Kaverin Ebonhand prosthetic hands out of an enchanted ebony-black rock. Once pressed against a fresh stump, the magic molded the black stone into the form of hands. The magic hands acted as if they were flesh and blood but were made out of stone.
;[[Ersatz eye]]
:A type of magical eye prosthetic.
;[[Pegleg of Immurk the Invincible]]
:A magical peg leg that was rumored to have been passed around by adventurers after its owner was lost at sea. When grafted onto a body it would shorten or lengthen to whatever length was appropriate for walking. It allowed its wearer to summon a [[parrot]] [[familiar]]. It could detect [[gold piece]]s within a {{SIAdj|100|ft|long=yes}} radius. It made the wearer incapable of becoming seasick and proficient in navigating, the use of [[harpoon]]s and [[rope]]s, swimming, sensing the weather, and general seamanship. And finally, three times per day the peg leg could be tapped against something to unleash a ''[[knock]]'' spell. Overall it was worth around 10,000 gold pieces.
document_data.History:
In the late 15{{th}} century DR, a barber in [[Silverymoon]] by the name of [[Jooge Nopsmoth]] would use his expertise in dentistry to replace troublesome teeth with prosthetics made of gold, silver, or porcelain. He also offered special [[iron]] teeth, which allowed his [[annis hag]] master to eavesdrop on their wearer.{{Cite dragon+/12/The Barber of Silverymoon|7}}

During this time period [[Arla Razortongue]] established the [[Peg and Hook]] in [[Luskan]], a prosthetics shop that unusually sold hooks meant to be worn in place of a leg and pegs meant to be worn in place of a hand. She managed to convince a number of pirates to try out this unorthodox method and later on would replace one of her own hands and legs with a peg and hook respectively.
